Authors:
Claire West, Stephen A James, Robert P Davey, Jo Dicks, Ian
N Roberts
Title:
Allele Frequencies in Yeast rDNA Tandem Arrays Follow
U-Shaped Distributions and can be used for Fine-Scaled Phylogenetic
Inference
Keywords:
ribosomal DNA, phylogenetic analysis, yeast, concerted
evolution, whole genome sequencing, genome hybridisation
Abstract:
The ribosomal RNA encapsulates a wealth of evolutionary
information, including genetic variation that can be used to
discriminate between organisms at a wide range of taxonomic levels.
Indeed, the prokaryotic 16S rDNA sequence is very widely used both in
phylogenetic studies and as a marker in metagenomic surveys and the ITS
region, frequently used in plant phylogenetics, is now recognised as a
fungal DNA barcode. However, this widespread use does not escape
criticism, principally due to issues such as difficulties in
classification of paralogous versus orthologous rDNA units and
intragenomic variation, both of which may be significant barriers to
accurate phylogenetic inference. In order to address the second of these
issues, rDNA sequence heterogenetity, while controlling for the first we
have used datasets from the Saccharomyces Genome Resequencing Project,
characterising rDNA sequence variation in unprecedented detail. In our
analysis of 34 strains of the bakerâ€™s yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae and
26 strains of the wild yeast Saccharomyces paradoxus, both of which
possess single locus rDNA systems, we identify 1,168 and 978
polymorphisms respectively. We further show that this variation, which
both contracts and proliferates under concerted evolutionary mechanisms,
follows U-shaped distributions in both species, similar to sets of loci
evolving under very different evolutionary mechanisms. We demonstrate
that a strong phylogenetic signal exists within both datasets and
illustrate how they can be used, with existing methodology, to estimate
intra-species phylogenies of yeast strains consistent with those derived
from whole-genome approaches. We also describe the use of partial Single
Nucleotide Polymorphisms, a type of sequence variation found only in
repetitive genomic regions, in identifying key evolutionary features
such as genome hybridisation events and show their consistency with
whole-genome Structure analyses. We discuss how, in future, new models
of concerted evolution could transform rDNA sequence heterogeneity from
a problem to a useful source of evolutionary information, enabling the
estimation of highly accurate phylogenies of closely related
organisms.
